title: How to use 'through' in addressing a formal letter - Quora

response.answer_text: How can I use "through" in addressing a formal letter? Without some context, this question is meaningless. If you clarify what you really want to do, you will probably get an answer that is actually helpful. My closest guess is that you might be addressing a letter to a particular person but wanting that person to pass it on. In both usual cases, you would not normally use the word, “through”. If you are addressing a letter to a specific individual — say, to Mr A Planner — within an organisation, but the letter should first go through the organisation’s filing systems, you would write something like The General ManagerLitchfield City Council42 Bent StreetLITCHFIELD 2990Attention: Mr A Planner (You can abbreviate Attention to Attn.) Similarly, if you were writing to a particular officer regardless of who that officer is, you might substitute that position, so: The General ManagerLitchfield City Council42 Bent StreetLITCHFIELD 2990Attn: Senior Development Control Officer The other common situation is where you want one individual to pass a letter on to another individual, where you usually use c/- or c/o (meaning care of): Miss Jenny Plannerc/- Mr A Planner7 Duisburg DriveLITCHFIELD NORTH 2990 Similarly, if you wanted to invite Mr Planner to a Parent Teacher night, but only had his work address, you might address it Mr A Planner, Senior Development Control Officerc/- Litchfield City Council42 Bent StreetLITCHFIELD 2990 (The italicised description is optional, but could be handy if the Planner family is a big one in the Litchfield area, and you don’t want a letter to Andrew Planner to go to his Uncle, Alf Palmer, one of the Council clerks.) Another way in which you might use a preposition — though “by”, rather than “through” — is if you are sending a letter using a particular means of delivery. This is of little importance these days, as most distance mail is delivered by air, but you might want to add a box at the top of an envelope containing the words, BY AIR MAIL or just AIR MAIL on the top left hand corner of the envelope. This is more likely to be an issue if the Post Office is offering some unusual means of delivery. If they are promoting the sesquicentenary of some traditional means, you might write BY CARRIER PIGEON However, it is probable that the Post Office would offer a sticker containing the same words. I hope that somewhere here your question is covered.

why are you trying to write ‘through’ on anything? rule of thumb is, if you cant find a way of putting a word somewhere, its probably the wrong one and you have millions of alternatives. who writes ‘through’ on a letter? nobody. why do you want to be the first? are you blogging about it? is it for a film? do you have youtube subscribers coercing you into badly addressing formal letters? NO!!!!… so behave do you want disgruntled postmasters coming to your house to hurt you? … because they will. try ‘care of’ on your envelope mate. … or C/O

You can’t use “through” in the salutation of the letter, the heading, or the inside address. It would make no sense. In the opening statement of the body of the letter, you can use “through” if you want to clarify the channels through which communication or the passing of knowledge took place, or is taking place now. I found your address through a mutual friend. I learned of the job opening through an advertisement in the Journal of Higher Education. Through the present letter, I hope to convince you that I am a candidate worthy of your consideration for this position. Allow me to express my deepest thanks through these few words.

If you mean its use in the address space, you may write it as shown below when you are not expected to send the communication direct to the actual addressee: The Director XYZ Company New Delhi - 110 011 (Through Proper Channel)

Through the advertisement of “The Daily Observer”I came to know that a few vaccant posts are going to be filled up at your earliest convenience. I would like to offer myself as a candidate for the same.
Don't use it. From a writing teacher.
